column2: Singapore;Bock- Heller Bock / Maibock;Brewerkz;A rare weak link at this Singaporean brewpub. Looked great - clear amber with extraordinary head retention. column2: Singapore;Bock- Heller Bock / Maibock;Brewerkz;I really wish they would do something about the name of this but they also have the Pilsner lager too. Names aside it is always a treat to visit this fine establishment in a very non-beer part of the world. A veritable oasis. I was probably a bit silly to go to the place as I cleared Singapore custons at about 10pm and I had to be up for a flight to Jakarta at 6 the next morning. aaah the things we do. At least I wasn’t disappointed. This looks fine in the shaker pint glass with a deep brown and good head that did disappear after a little time. Malt and chocolate dominate with a slight hint of fruitiness but not as pronouned at that noted by Per (shit
column3: I just saw he in on over 7k of ratings!!!). Low bitterness and a lack of real bock grunt overall. Good but not great.

A cracking session Old Ale and knocks the spots off Tit for Tat anyday. Well recommended.

column3: Canada;Altbier / Sticke Alt;Brasserie Dieu du Ciel!;Un corps plutôt rougeâtre et un anneau de mousse. Des parfums qui frappent. Des feuilles en décomposition et de la terre stagnante minimalement soutenues par des céréales grillées. Un goût inintéressant fabriqué par des houblons agressifs et par une flaveur étrangement cartonnée. Un corps de faible densité avec une texture mince. Un pétillement normal. Une finale qui brutalise mes papilles avec une amertume non-identifiable. Il me semble que cette bière expose un caractère drôlement problématique. À reboire pour confirmer le tout? Non merci.

column4: herbs and grass clippings. Some paper
column5: soapiness and alcohol also show up. Firm and snug carbonation. Opens with a “candyish” Franconian yeast character that’s swiftly lifted by minerals and hop-derived nectar. A budding grassy and woody bitterness makes a memorable impression with its staunch smack. Touches of fennel candy help give the perception of sweetness and supply some heft to the quite slender body
column6: but the lack of malt vividness and hoppy succulence is sadly felt. Prominent alcohol creates dissonance as it collides with the tannic

column8: though a brightening splash of lemon juice offers temporary relief and much needed levity. The sharp finish is laced with hoppy acids and dry

column10: but it’s certainly not a bad pils by any means.

Japan;Belgian Ale - Pale / Golden;Yo-Ho Brewing Company;Can. On my second to last day in Tokyo I was told that in the basement of big department stores they sell microbrews. If I had only found out earlier. After careful deliberation and help at translating the writing on the cans I bought five beers. This was one of the best. It had an amber color with a white head. column1: Hong Kong Beer Co. Dragon's Back IPA;Chai Wan
column2: Hong Kong;Brown Ale;Hong Kong Beer Co.;The story around his ale is actually better than the beer itself. Anyway it was a really nice brown ale. Not an IPA as the label says. Once upon a time Monika was in Germany with her dogs again
column3: and off course she had to do some beer shopping for me. By a coincidence I did see that some other lads had bought a beer from Hong Kong at a grocery store close to where she camped. So…… Well she found them and I was happy. A whole crate actually. Yeah I could trade a lot with these. My good pal Terje should off course get one. And when we sat down in his space rocket we discovered that it was an IPA
column4: not the expected pale shait. Ahhhh damned we could not drink it that day and I wanted to taste it as well. Okey so he kept it in his closet at work. Well we thought we could share it quite soon…….due to a wild bicycle race
column5: Ullevål Hospital and other small events….it stayed in that WARM closet for almost 1
column6: 5 year. Should we ever manage to kill this one? Off course we are proper gentleman and do not waste beer. Well it was a thick
column7: so….well at last the moment arrived. On a bus
column9: on our way to a beer festival
column10: surrounded by a whole lot of football hooligans. Mama mia. Well the bald football fans are actually my friends and probably the kindest football and beer lovers in the known universe. The Hong Kong IPA turned out to be a fine brown ale
column11: and the storing in Terjes closet at work had not killed it at all. BB was passed 8 months ago. But we survived. Maybe the plastic cups from Østfold Hospital had some antibiotics that helped us. Who knows
column12: but I will always remember this one. Cheers!

column3: United States;Märzen / Oktoberfest Bier;Great Lakes Brewing (Ohio);The pour was surprisingly fun. It gathered a frothy
column4: lightly orange head that covered the glass with perfect lacing. Its bubbly amber color was clear. The aroma was very subtle
column5: but it sweet and toasty. Its texture was refreshing and very smooth. The taste is incredibly smooth
column6: yet satisfying. The toasty malt flavor lingers on. Considering how much I haven't liked smooth Oktoberfest beers
column7: I actually like this one a lot. While it is crisp and easy to drink
column8: it has layers that other smooth Märzen beers are missing. I highly recommend this forum an American Märzen-style lager.

Malt takes on a grassy hay dimension which echoes the grassy hop aspects. Lemony splash of well-integrated hops ensues

United States;Bock - Eisbock;New Glarus Brewing Company;"For review #5
column5: this milestone beer had an interesting story of how it was acquired in the first place. When I attended the Great Taste of the Midwest 2012
column6: I was disenchanted as I noticed my favorite food vendor
column8: didn’t set up a food stand at the festival. What’s this? No Wisconsin limburger cheese on rye with red onions
column9: and a bottle of Blumers root beer for lunch this year? We can’t have that! This was the first time in ten years Baumgartner’s didn’t show up and I had to modify my festival routine this year. Well
column11: I stopped at Baumgartner’s in Monroe while visiting the southwest breweries of Wisconsin. As I was writing a few beer reviews on my iPad
column12: a gentleman sitting next to me noticed me updating ratebeer database and started a conversation with me about some of the historical breweries of Wisconsin. I would never turn down an opportunity to archive more beer history so we talked for over an hour. During our conversation
column13: he said he used to work for New Glarus Brewing Company. He also mentioned that he still had a bottle of New Glarus Symposium Eisbock in his cellar. I asked him what would it take for me to purchase the bottle of New Glarus Symposium Eisbock from him? He said ""Buy me a round of beer and it’s yours."" He came back 20 minutes later and handed me the bottle (the one featured in this profile page). Not only did I bought him a round of beer
column14: I bought him lunch and three rounds of beer for his generosity. A month later I stopped at Baumgartner’s again and the gentleman was there too. I bought him two more rounds of beer. So when you are visiting breweries and writing beer reviews
column15: always make time to talk to curious people who are observing what you are doing. You’ll never know what they may offer you. From a 12-oz bottle pours a hazy dark yellowish brown colored brew with no head
column16: yet a thin beige film top slowly dissipates. Aroma of brown sugar
column17: a hint of soy and mild raisin and dark pitted fruit. Taste is medium to full bodied
column18: very little carbonation if any with flavors of powdery roasted dark malts
column20: brown sugar some prune and toffee. Finish is quite smooth
column21: a tad on the sweet side with aftertastes if oxidized caramel malts
column22: brown sugar and a touch of soy. Everything I expected from a 12-year old bottle of Eisbock."

I'm not exactly sure if the various flavours are really working all that well together. I'm now on my last pour and....the foam is really thick and billowy now with the clarity I mentioned earlier being replaced by a murky amber and the flavours seem to be meshing more favourably so I'm starting to like this Doppelbock more. The taste also has some dark chocolate and roasted coffee on top of a big sweet malt base. The finish has a big toasted malt taste that lingers in the aftertaste with a definite alcohol burn. The mouthfeel is medium bodied and smooth with minimal carbonation. I enjoyed this beer and it is a pretty drinkable impy stout despite the big roasty profile. Recommended.

column3: United States;Märzen / Oktoberfest Bier;Empire Brewing Company;Copper orange Color. My friend who works there got this in a keg for a bunch of us. It was fresh off the first vat they produced in 2002. This was my first oktoberfest I had ever tried and was quite a memorable experience. It began with a nice fresh malt taste and then was backed by a wonderfully clean hop flavor that lingered on into the finish. Alcohol did not interfere
column4: only added to the full flavor. Had I not known I would have thought this beer had been cellared due to its balanced even flavor. Upon warming
column5: the beer brought forth some grassy/alcohol notes and the body stood up wonderfully still polishing off with some malty hop goodness with only minimal notes of sweetness to compliment. What kept striking me was how fresh this beer tasted and how much of a difference that makes. I knew this beer was destined for greatness and I told my friend this had to win a medal. Sure enough
column7: it took gold at the GABF. What an experience.

column3: United States;Bitter - Premium / Strong / ESB;Blue Point Brewing (AB InBev);Huge thanks to cosmicevan for getting me a growler of this. Finally

column6: which is a bit strange. Light nuttiness there as well along with some earthy and herbal hops. The flavor takes down the malt a touch and focuses slightly more on the hops. Not quite the best ESB that I’ve ever had -- that honor goes to FFF Lord Admiral Nelson -- but this is a good beer

column2: Syria;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Al-Chark Brewery;A Mes rate: 33cl bottle kindly bought back by my flatmate Rob from Syria. Very very odd stuff. A huge deposit of sediment in the bottle. Looks almost like the honey stuff you get at the bottom of a Bieken but far more of it. Chunky nose of hops with some butterscotch. Very cloudy looks with a bubbly and soapy head. Bags of butterscotch and toffee in the flavour accompanied by some dusty old tobacco notes too. Finish is nasty and spoils it considerably. SilkTork???

column2: Syria;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Al-Chark Brewery;This is a wonderful beer
column3: an astonishing shock considering it''s made in Muslim Syria. Unfortunately it''s hard to get hold of - the disgusting beer from Damascus
column4: the capital of Syria
column5: is available almost everywhere
column6: but I only found this in a cafe near Saladin''s Castle not far from the coast. Frustratingly when we stayed in Aleppo we were in a Muslim hotel next to a mosque and so were served a non-alcoholic Almaza. The beer comes in generous 1.5 litre bottles and is very fruity
column8: but with some grapefruit present. For a lager I found this to be full of complex flavours
column10: and the malt body firm and distinctive. Five different bottles were tasted by seven people and all agreed that this was astonishingly excellent. Given more time to track down a supplier I would have brought back a case load. Worth going to Syria just to sample this jewel!

column3: United States;Weissbier - Hefeweizen;F.X. Matt Brewing Company;Saranac’s Hefeweizen has a cloudy golden color with a thin foamy head. The aroma of banana is very strong. There is also a hint of spice and wheat in the aroma as well. Its flavor is mostly sweet with very little hop presence. There is a heavy dose of banana and lemon flavors along with a wheat malt base and some spicy clove. All of this is wrapped up in a medium body with a smooth texture and a mild carbonation. Another solid offering from Saranac.

Finish is a bitter linger that hangs for a few minutes on the back of my throat.

column6: after the head settled later that day

column8: the flavor would have made more sense if the brewer was Vlassic. The taste was very sour with more than a hint of dill. The mouthfeel was similar to Classic Coke with enough carbonation to lift Skylab back into space. The only good thing about the finish was that it eventually finished. Either this was a bad bottle or Island is a bad brewey (or has a poor bottling line with weak QC). Thankfully
column9: a Stone Smoked Porter was in the fridge and worked its magic soon after this one hit the bottom of the drain.

column3: United States;Brown Ale;Island Brewing;I don’t know what is going on with these guys but it seems like almost every time I pick up one of their brews there is something seriously wrong with it. I’m surprised more people don’t complain of this because I was noticing this exact same flavor in several of their other brews about 6 months ago. I’m not sure if its infected
column4: or sunlight
column5: or old or what. But all I really detect as far as taste and smell is sour vinegar. I ended up dumping this one and hate letting beer go to waste. In the flavor I tried to see paste the awful sourness and detected a slight maltiness. Forget it. I’ve just had way too many bad bottles from these guys. They need to get their crap figured out before they ship out any more bottles.

column4: I have an affinity for Il Vicino because I loved this place when I lived in ABQ (their IPA is among my fondest memories). Unfortunately I hadn’t discovered RateBeer when I lived there. I had the chance to sample this at their STL location and believe this is a perfect beer ... pure amber with an awesome standing head and a great restrained hop aroma and solid mouthfeel. It’s perfectly balanced ... lightly hopped and citricly sweet beer on a light caramel malt beer. Perfect.

column3: Australia;Pale Ale - American / APA;Wig & Pen Brewery;180715. This is my first beer from Wig & Pen and it is most unusual to find their beers outside of Canberra. This pale ale was on tap at The Scratch - I think the guys from The Scratch possibly get these beers because they are originally from Canberra. This is a good strong pale ale with everything that you want in a beer. While not earth shatteringly great it is by no means below par. Toffee butterscotch colour with the slightest of heads. Full flavoured with no bitterness at all. Flavour wise this beers probably sits in the mid range but there are flavours of hops and citrus and also some floral hops in the aroma - nothing over the top. A good solid beer that I would recommend seeking out if you can.

column3: United States;Red Ale / Intl Amber Ale;Bozeman Brewing Company;"Transfer from BA review on 5-4-14- Poured from can into a pint glass Appearance – The beer pours a deep amber color with a one finger head of white billowy foam. The head has a lighter level of retention
column4: fading to leave a tiny level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass. Smell – The aroma of the beer is mainly of a caramel aroma with light hints of a roasted malt smell mixed within. Some very light floral and herbal smells are there as well helping to balance out the caramel smells. Taste – The taste begins with a smoother lightly toasted malt and caramel flavor. The caramel flavor gains strength toward the middle only to fade again more toward the end of the taste. All the while the roasted malt flavors remain relatively constant
column5: creating a base flavor for the brew. As the nose would have suggested
column6: some hop flavors come at the end of the taste with a floral
column8: and earthy hop flavor all making their presence known. In the end
column9: these hop flavors end up mixing with the rest of the flavors to leave a rather smooth and pleasant lightly roasted caramel flavor to linger on the tongue. Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is on the average side in terms of thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that is on the average side. The mouthfeel is rather nice for the amber ale style while also being great for the easy drinking nature of the brew
column10: Overall – A tasty and very easy drinking amber ale. While not anything too outstanding overall
column11: it is a good 6 packer beer to share with friends as it is flavorful and very non offensive; good for just about any taste preference."

The taste is better now that it’s warmer as the hops and their stiffness and weak pinyness comes out swinging. Zero grapefruit or other strong related citrus fruits that are so common. Some malt backbone...actually more than just some. Mouthfeel is thinner than I’m used to. Breathing in some harshness (good!). Finishes with a so-so bitter taste...but it’s got legs. A good change up from a hop pounding. I’ll get this again me thinks.

column6: some herbs. Finish is short with almost no bitterness. This is an excellent light session beer with the wheat/caramel duo as the main attraction. Caramelised but without loosing its crisp wheaty body. Something I wish I could drink on a regular basis. Having walked downtown New York on a number of occasions I thought that the Chelsea Autumn Harvest consisted of gathering used condoms and needles from the West Side Manhattan sidewalks before winter.

column3: United States;Stout - Dry;C.H. Evans Brewing Company at the Albany Pump Station;A - Pours a dark black color with a hint of brown around the edge with a finger of creamy off-white/tan head. Also a little bit of milk sweetness in the background. Through the middle some really deep roasted flavors come through alongside some chocolate malts. Finish is very roasty and malty and lingers very nicely. M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Very smooth and creamy with a little bit of a milky feel and a very nice and dry finish. D - Very drinkable. Could use a touch more flavor

column5: caramel

column3: United States;Brown Ale;Bubes Brewery;Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a semi-dark brown color with an off white foamy head that fell off at a decent pace. Light stringy sliding lace. The flavor was moderately sweet with the roast of the nuts and malts coming through fairly nice. Slight milk chocolate smoothness rolling through the aftertaste and on into the finish. The palate was almost medium bodied with a pretty good sessionability about it. ABV felt good and it came across super smooth rolling all around my tongue. Overall

column5: but the funkiness of it was really quite appealing. It isn’t all abrasive fruitiness though
column6: the malts are soft enough in their own right to provide a pear and apricot background that is both subtle and calming. The aromas on this guy are really quite satisfying. Well balanced and interesting all at once. On the first sip the blue cheese jumps out of the glass and then falls slightly under the weight of the hop whallop as the malts die off slowly. Apricots and bitterness linger. If I brewed a barleywine I would want it to taste like this.

column2: Ghana;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Guinness Ghana Breweries;My third Third World pale lager in three days and my devotion to racking up a healthy country tick count is showing somes signs of strain. First of all
column3: it seems to be some sort of west African tradition to sell massive 625ml bottles when a sampler would do me just fine
column4: but I guess no one said this was going to be an easy job. Just buckle down and get through it. Pours clear gold from the bottle and leaves a white head of relatively short retention. Aroma is cereal
column5: a bit of honey. Taste is lightly sweet
column6: finish is short with a light grainy bitterness. The palate is nice — smooth and refreshing. But overall this is a fairly generic pale lager without a lot of character. Still over half the bottle left and my mood is souring. A really bad beer would be easy — drainpour and the next please. But this one is just over the border of pale lager decency. It tortures you with golden reproach — I came all the way from Africa
column8: you can’t just throw me down the drain! You paid more for me than some people in Ghana earn in a day. And still it sits there
column10: and now it’s going flat. It’s not going to get any better. And there is a black IPA waiting in the fridge. Do I want to spend my whole alcohol for the night on this? Thank God there’s always the wife to bail me out of problems like this.

column6: just the oak. The flavor adds in a good bit of booze. There’s roast and chocolate there as well. The oak and vanilla aren’t as prevalent as in the nose. The heat certainly takes it down a notch from where the nose was
column7: which is surprising given the age and the fact that this is fairly-low in alcohol. Body is medium with light carbonation and a bit of booze through the finish. Overall
column8: pretty good and I’m very glad I finally got to try this one."

column1: Magic Hat Thumbsucker Imperial Stout;South Burlington
column3: United States;Stout - Imperial;Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO);Bottle courtesy of Lubiere: Poured a pitch-black color stout with a small dark brown foamy head with good retention and some light lacing. Aroma of fruit cake with light port notes. Taste has probably lost some of the characteristics related to an imperial stout due to aging which have been replaced with nice notes of port and fruit cake with light dry roasted malt notes still perceptible. Description mentions bourbon aging though I can’t say that I could taste any notes of bourbon. Body is about average with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Still good after all those years but I have to wonder what I fresh version would taste like.

column1: Magic Hat Thumbsucker Imperial Stout;South Burlington
column3: United States;Stout - Imperial;Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO);From Notes sampled 11/11/2007 I bought a growler or two from the brewery. Pours an opaque brown/black with a very minimal tan head
column4: very low carbonation here. Aroma comes through with strong bourbon and alcohol and some dried fruits. Tastes almost port like with some roasted malt bitterness. Raisins and bourbon come through as well. Mouthfeel is thinnner than I expected
column5: but leaves a roasty figgy aftertaste. A great RIS very complex beer. I’m not sure I believe that this beer is 7.8% abv might be artificially low to get around Vermont’s ancient beer laws. I wish they would bottle this again so I could see how it ages.

column1: Magic Hat Thumbsucker Imperial Stout;South Burlington
column3: United States;Stout - Imperial;Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO);Draft and growler serving some time in 2007 when i day tripped up to the brewery. I was told the etoh was closer to 11-12% and what i was drinking was in the barrel close to 4 years. One beer not to be taken lightly. This colossal imperial stout poured like black ink with a tin dark brown lacing that quickly dissipated. Huge dark chocolate malt and bourbon in the nose. Even more so in the taste with a big warming alcohol character and some light vanilla. Viscous on the boarder of syrupy. This beer is awesome. We had a sick time camping out in the woods for Reuben’s birthday with this brew.
